Articles.Content:
One off the holding locks didn't open and the the stage didn't detach. The orbit's closest point is 65 miles away.

Article here.http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/technology/russian-military-satellite-suffers-launch-failure-will-crash-soon/ar-AAg80pF?li=BBnbcA1&ocid=iehp

As it was the soyuz 2.1v, guess we are seeing the teething issues of the volga upperstage here (as it's devellopment was started back in 2008)

 

Though, i wonder why the journalists had to mention the manned version of soyuz... current Manned soyuz flights take place on the much older soyuz-FG (which is not even concerned by volga...)
The bolt that didn't fire, and apparently the rest of the payload interface, was built at the old PO Polyot plant, now a Krunichev subsidiary; so it looks like yet another Krunichev QA issue.
Will there be anything left to recover? As this is considered a military satellite, I imagine they would want to recover what they can.

"Crash"? They should've said it's a russian attack on something. More drama!

It's simply burned up yesterday (just five hours after the OP), the last tracked position was 35S 1W.

Edited December 9, 2015 by J.Random
^ "Die, random fish in the middle of the ocean! For the motherland!!!" xD
